inclusion.criterion: T50-Test The addition of calcium and phosphate to serum triggers the formation of primary calciprotein particles (CPP, see figures 2 and 3). As nano-suspension of calcium-phosphate, these particles represent a defense mechanism of the serum against calcification. Primary CPPs undergo spontaneous transition to secondary CPPs. The formation of these particles represents calcification. In the T50-Test, the time elapsed for the transformation of 50% of the particles is measured and is specific for individual sera.
inclusion.label: unknown
